div.l: Til it be roten
can we nat be rype
We hoppen alwey / whil the worlde wol pipe
For in our wyl ther styketh eủer a nayl
We haue an hore heed / and a grene tail
As hath a leek / for thouh our myht be gon
Our wyl desyreth foly euer a non
For whan we may nat do / thanne wol we speke
Yit in our aisshen̄ / olde fier is reke
Foure gledys / haue we / whiche I shal devyse
Avauntyng / lyeng / Angir / and covetyse
Thes foure sperkyl / longen̄ vnto the elde
Our elde bonys / mon wel ben vnwelde
But wyl shal nat failen / that is soth
For yet haue I alwey a coltys toth
And many a yer / is it passed henne
Syn that myn tappe / of lyf bi gan to renne
For sykyrly whan̄ y was born̄ a non̄
Deth drowe the tappe of lyve / and let it gon̄
And evir syth / hath so the tappe y ronne
Tyl that al most al empty is the tonne
The strem of lyf / droppeth on the chyme
The sely tong / may wel ryng and chymbe
Of wrechednesse / that passed is ful yore
Wyth olde folke / save dotage / ther is no mor͗e
Whanne that our ost / hadde herd this sermoıı̄unyng
He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
He seid / what amounteth al this wyt
What shal we speke alday of holy wryt
The devyl maad a reeve / for to preche
Or of a souter / a shipman or a leche
Sey forth thi tale / and tary nat thy tyme
Lo depforde / and it is half wey to pryme
